awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Theoretical Foundations of Symmetric Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Cryptography is essential to ensure confidentiality and integrity of information. Due to their practicality, symmetric algorithms ­­ where the same secret key is used by the sender and the recipient ­­ underlie most practical deployments of cryptographic techniques. However, also as a result of this, symmetric cryptography suffers from an inherent tension between real ­world efficiency demands and provable security guarantees. This project investigates new technical advances aimed at narrowing the gap between provable security and the practical demands of symmetric cryptography.

The project develops new cryptographic algorithms and proof techniques, drawing from techniques in theoretical computer science, applied mathematics, and information theory. This involves the study of combinatorial problems whose solutions yield security proofs for existing and new encryption paradigms, and the development of new provably secure methods to encrypt data from arbitrary domains. The project identifies widely deployed cryptographic methods without provable security guarantees, introduces new assumptions on their components and new frameworks to validate their security with proofs, and explores the trade­off between efficiency and security of symmetric cryptographic algorithms. The project will organize an annual cryptography academy targeted at economically disadvantaged high-school students, to increase their interest and representation in computing.

por.por_cntn:
Symmetric cryptography considers algorithms meant to protect the confidentiality and integrity of data in settings where the sender and the receiver share a secret key. These algorithms are the workhorses of practical cryptography and are extremely efficient. 

However, their theoretical study is very challenging, and their security very often relies on heuristics. This project has made major advances in the theoretical study of symmetric cryptography. Its findings have led to new and better proofs of security for existing symmetric cryptography, have supported the design of new algorithms, and have uncovered flaws in in-use methods. 

Some highlights of this project include:

1. New proof techniques based on tools from theoretical computer science, information theory and statistics that have improved our understanding of existing algorithms, including the Advanced Encryption Standard, and supported the design of new ones.

2. Attacks on Format-Preserving Encryption (FPE), a cryptographic method widely adopted to protect databases and financial transactions, which have led to the revision of existing standards.

3. New theoretical advances in the analysis and design of Random Number Generators (RNGs), the component of an operating system meant to generate pseudorandom bits, which have guided the development of new practical approaches.

4. New generic techniques to protect symmetric cryptography from quantum attackers. 

The broader impacts of the project include the development of a new class on applied cryptography as part of the professional master program at the University of Washington, as well as a new cryptography academy for high-school students aimed at increasing first-generation college students in computer science and STEM. Research of this project has also supported the development of platforms for privacy-preserving contact tracing which have been part of the digital response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The project has also supported several graduate students.
